title: 111_s788
content: The "m-SPAM Act of 2009" is cited as the short title of this Act. Certain qualifying messages are exempted from the definition of mobile service commercial message. The CAN-SPAM Act of 2003 is amended to define "commercial mobile service" and "mobile service commercial message" as related to electronic mail messages sent to wireless devices. The CAN-SPAM Act of 2003 is amended to define "commercial mobile service" and "mobile service commercial message" as related to electronic mail messages sent to wireless devices. It includes unsolicited messages sent to subscribers without prior agreement. The CAN-SPAM Act of 2003 defines "commercial mobile service" and "mobile service commercial message" for electronic mail messages to wireless devices. It excludes unsolicited messages sent without prior agreement. The CAN-SPAM Act of 2003 defines "commercial mobile service" and "mobile service commercial message" for electronic mail messages to wireless devices. It excludes unsolicited messages sent without prior agreement. The Act allows messages to provide warranty, product recall, safety, or security information for purchased products or ongoing commercial relationships. The CAN-SPAM Act of 2003 defines "commercial mobile service" and "mobile service commercial message" for electronic mail messages to wireless devices, excluding unsolicited messages. It allows messages to provide notices about changes in terms or status of ongoing commercial relationships. The CAN-SPAM Act of 2003 allows messages to provide notices about changes in terms or status of ongoing commercial relationships, including account balance information or account statements. The CAN-SPAM Act of 2003 allows messages to provide information directly related to an employment relationship or related benefit plan, or deliver goods and services. The CAN-SPAM Act of 2003 allows messages to provide information related to an employment relationship, benefits, deliver goods or services, including updates or upgrades, that the recipient is entitled to receive under a transaction previously agreed upon. The term 'short message' refers to a text or other message sent to a telephone number or identifier other than an email address assigned to a wireless device. The CAN-SPAM Act of 2003 allows messages related to employment, benefits, goods, or services agreed upon. It does not prohibit sending short messages to a telephone number or identifier assigned to a wireless device. The CAN-SPAM Act of 2003 allows sending short messages between wireless devices or from a commercial mobile service provider to its subscribers at no cost, unless a subscriber opts out of receiving such messages. The CAN-SPAM Act of 2003 permits commercial mobile service providers to send messages to subscribers at no charge unless the subscriber opts out. Amendments to the Act require providers to comply with regulations regarding commercial mobile services. PROHIBITION ON UNAUTHORIZED MOBILE SERVICE COMMERCIAL MESSAGES WITH UNSOLICITED ADVERTISEMENTS. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to prohibit sending mobile service commercial messages to individuals without their prior authorization. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to include definitions related to commercial mobile service and mobile service commercial messages. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to include definitions related to commercial mobile service and mobile service commercial messages. The prohibition on mobile service commercial messages does not apply to sending short messages between wireless devices. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to include definitions related to commercial mobile service and mobile service commercial messages. The Act prohibits the sending of mobile service commercial messages by providers to subscribers unless the subscriber has opted in to receive them. The Act prohibits providers from sending mobile service commercial messages to subscribers who have opted out. State law authority remains unchanged compared to commercial electronic mail messages under the CAN-SPAM Act of 2003. SEC. 4 prohibits unsolicited advertisements sent to cellular phones. The Federal Trade Commission will update the do-not-call registry rules to address costly or annoying commercial mobile service messaging practices and explicitly ban sending commercial messages to numbers on the registry assigned to commercial mobile services. The Federal Trade Commission will update the do-not-call registry rules to explicitly ban sending commercial messages to numbers on the registry assigned to commercial mobile services, except for messages sent by a provider of commercial mobile service to its subscribers at no charge. The terms "mobile service commercial message" and "commercial mobile service" are defined in relevant sections of the CAN-SPAM Act of 2003 and the Communications Act of 1934.
